label.text: Wheat Crop
Wheat is a species of grass that produces edible grains (cereal). It is the most widely grown cereal crop in the world.

Satellite imaging can be used to monitor wheat crops that grow on flat farmland. The images identify areas where wheat is growing. Data from the images are analysed by computer modelling. Farmers use this information to maximise the amount of wheat produced.
Since satellites operate at great distances from Earth’s surface, the smallest area of farmland that the satellite can detect is 500 m × 500 m. In a satellite image, this area is equal to one pixel.
1 pixel in satellite image = 500 m × 500 m of farmland.

Traditionally, wheat crop yields are estimated from the ground.
What is one advantage of using satellite imaging data to estimate crop yields compared to estimation from the ground?
Satellite imaging is faster and less labour intensive.
Satellite imaging more accurately determines crop type.
Ground observation cannot identify variations in crop yield.
Ground observation can only be conducted once during the growing season.
The computer model analyses satellite images to determine the total area of farmland where wheat is ready to be harvested.
What other data would be needed to estimate the total mass of wheat grain that could be harvested from the farmland?
the average mass of wheat that could be harvested per area
the quality of the soil in which the wheat grows
previous total yields of wheat that was grown on the farmland
the number of pixels in the satellite images of the farmland
